steps.title: Look at the dog's size.
steps.content: Look at the dog's size. Dachshunds come in two sizes: standard and miniature. Standard Dachshunds are 8–9 inches (20–23 cm) in height and 16–32 pounds (7.3–14.5 kg) in weight, while miniature Dachshunds are typically 5–6 inches (13–15 cm) tall and weigh 11 pounds (5.0 kg) or less. steps.title: Notice the ears.
steps.content: Notice the ears. Dachshunds have moderately long, round ears. [4] X Trustworthy Source American Kennel Club Expert knowledge, resources and advice for all things dog-related. steps.title: Check the eyes.
steps.content: Check the eyes. Dachshunds have medium-sized, almond-shaped eyes. Look for dark eyes that give the dog a pleasant and energetic expression. [5] X Trustworthy Source American Kennel Club Expert knowledge, resources and advice for all things dog-related. Go to source

steps.title: Look at the tail.
steps.content: Look at the tail. The tail of a Dachshund is slim. It is described as being "set in continuation of the spine". [6] X Trustworthy Source American Kennel Club Expert knowledge, resources and advice for all things dog-related. Go to source

steps.title: Inspect the overall structure.
steps.content: Inspect the overall structure. Dachshunds have a recognizable structure: their bodies are long and low-set, with short legs. They are fairly muscular and have a smooth gait. steps.title: Differentiate between coat types.
steps.content: Differentiate between coat types. Dachshunds can be seen sporting three different types of coats: smooth, wirehaired, or longhaired. Smooth Dachshunds have short, smooth, shining coats that aren't too long or thick. [8] X Trustworthy Source American Kennel Club Expert knowledge, resources and advice for all things dog-related. Go to source Wirehaired Dachshunds have short, thick, rough, hard outer coats and softer, finer undercoats. [9] X Trustworthy Source American Kennel Club Expert knowledge, resources and advice for all things dog-related. Go to source Longhaired Dachshunds have sleek, glistening coats that are sometimes slightly wavy. steps.title: Identify the coat color.
steps.content: Identify the coat color. Dachshunds have a wide range of acceptable colors, from one solid color to two colors. Common solid coat colors are red and cream, and colors frequently seen on a two-colored coat are black, chocolate, wild boar, grey/blue, and fawn, with tan or cream markings on the face, throat, chest, legs/paws, and tail. steps.title: Check the coat pattern.
steps.content: Check the coat pattern. Though not all Dachshunds have patterns and are just seen with solid coats, coat patterns such as merle and brindle are common in Dachshunds. Dapple/Merle coats are coats with spots of a lighter shade on a dark base color. [12] X Trustworthy Source American Kennel Club Expert knowledge, resources and advice for all things dog-related. steps.title: Watch for loyalty.
steps.content: Watch for loyalty. Due to their independence, Dachshunds may take a while to understand who's in charge. However, once they do, they can become loyal, devoted pets. [18] X Research source

steps.title: See if the dog is stubborn.
steps.content: See if the dog is stubborn. Dachshunds exhibit stubbornness alongside their independence. They may be hesitant to follow directions, even if they are told to do something they want to do. [19] X Research source

steps.title: Expect barking.
steps.content: Expect barking. Bred to hunt, a Dachshund may be full of energy, causing it to bark at many things. Anticipate barking and a desire to run around from a Dachshund. [20] X Research source

steps.title: Check for liveliness.
steps.content: Check for liveliness. Dachshunds are a playful, lively breed. See if the dog enjoys playing or making games out of simple activities. [22] X Research source
